node.title: Can Glasgow Deliver on a Global Climate Deal?
node.alt: A meeting of the Coalition of Finance Ministers for Climate Action in Glasgow last week.
node.description: Negotiators from about 200 countries are entering Week 2 of climate talks trying to resolve big issues around money, transparency and timelines.
node.content: ["GLASGOW \u2014 The international climate summit here has been billed as the \u201clast, best hope\u201d to save the planet. But as the United Nations conference enters its second week and negotiators from 197 countries knuckle down to finalize a new agreement to tackle global warming, attendees were sharply divided over how much progress is being made.", "There\u2019s the optimistic view: Heads of state and titans of industry showed up in force last week with splashy new climate promises, a sign that momentum was building in the right direction.", "\u201cI believe what is happening here is far from business as usual,\u201d said John Kerry, President Biden\u2019s special envoy on climate change, who has been attending U.N. climate summits since 1992. \u201cI have never counted as many initiatives and as much real money \u2014 real money \u2014 being put on the table.\u201d", "For example, 105 countries agreed to cut emissions of methane, a potent planet-warming gas, by 30 percent this decade. Another 130 countries vowed to halt deforestation by 2030 and commit billions of dollars toward the effort. India for the first time joined the growing chorus of nations pledging to reach \u201cnet zero\u201d emissions, setting a 2070 deadline to stop adding greenhouse gases to the atmosphere.", "Then there\u2019s the pessimistic view: All these gauzy promises mean little without concrete plans to follow through. And that\u2019s still lacking. Or, as the Swedish activist Greta Thunberg put it, the conference has mostly consisted of \u201cblah, blah, blah.\u201d", "Malik Amin Aslam, an adviser to the prime minister of Pakistan, scoffed at some of the distant net zero goals being announced, including India\u2019s: \u201cWith an average age of 60, I don\u2019t think anyone in the negotiating room would live to experience that net zero in 2070,\u201d he said.", "Critics noted that some of last week\u2019s announcements turned out to be full of caveats. After signing the forest pledge, officials in Indonesia, home to the world\u2019s third-largest rainforest, clarified that ending deforestation in their country by 2030 at the expense of economic development was \u201cobviously inappropriate and unfair.\u201d Another vow by more than 40 countries to phase out coal power featured vague timelines and left out major coal users like China, India and the United States.", "\u201cThe actual negotiations here are in danger of being drowned out by a blitz of news releases that get great headlines, but are often less than meets the eye,\u201d said Mohamed Adow, director of Power Shift Africa, a research institute based in Kenya. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of good talk and less real action.\u201d", "Mr. Adow said the summit should be judged on whether all 197 parties can craft a detailed, formal agreement that holds governments accountable for the promises they make. That would mean reaching consensus on wonky but crucial questions like how often nations should strengthen their near-term plans to cut emissions, the amount and type of financial aid that rich countries should give poorer ones to cope with the mounting dangers of climate change, and how to regulate the booming global market in carbon offsets.", "Behind closed doors, negotiators are still debating key issues as they seek to expand and update the landmark 2015 Paris climate agreement. By tradition, a final agreement requires every single country to sign on \u2014 if any one of them objects, talks can deadlock.", "How these disputes get resolved by the time the summit ends on Friday could determine the success of the Glasgow talks.", "\u201cThe reality is you\u2019ve got two different truths going on,\u201d said Helen Mountford, vice president for climate and economics at the World Resources Institute. \u201cWe\u2019ve made much more progress than we ever could\u2019ve imagined a couple years ago. But it\u2019s still nowhere near enough.\u201d", "When the conference opened last Monday, the U.N. secretary general, Ant\u00f3nio Guterres, said the top priority must be to limit the rise in global temperatures to just 1.5 degrees Celsius, or 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit, above preindustrial levels. That\u2019s the threshold, scientists have warned, beyond which the risk of calamities like deadly heat waves, water shortages and ecosystem collapse grows immensely. (The world has already warmed 1.1 degrees Celsius.)", "Countries are all but certain to leave Glasgow short of achieving that goal. The big question is whether the lofty pledges this week, along with a new formal agreement, can push them further along.", "When analysts at the United Nations tallied up all of the formal plans that nations have submitted so far to curb emissions over the next decade, they estimated that the world was on track to heat up roughly 2.7 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels by 2100. That\u2019s both an improvement over where things stood a decade ago and also far off-track.", "To limit warming to just 1.5 degrees Celsius, the U.N. said, global emissions from fossil fuels need to plummet by roughly half between 2010 and 2030. Instead, emissions are set to rise over that period.", "\u201cRecent climate action announcements might give the impression that we are on track to turn things around,\u201d Mr. Guterres said last week. \u201cThis is an illusion.\u201d", "On Thursday, however, the International Energy Agency offered a more hopeful picture. If you factor in some of the longer term, less-detailed promises that countries have made this week \u2014 including pledges to reach net zero emissions by most of the world\u2019s biggest economies, as well as the global agreement to cut methane \u2014 then the world could potentially keep warming to as low as 1.8 degrees Celsius by 2100.", "\u201cI certainly never thought we\u2019d get to next Friday confidently on track to 1.5 degrees, but if we can break the two-degree barrier, I think psychologically that will be huge and maybe give us more of a collective belief that we can go faster,\u201d said Nigel Topping, chosen by the U.N. as its \u201chigh level climate action champion.\u201d", "Yet many environmentalists remained skeptical of the International Energy Agency\u2019s projection.", "\u201cIt\u2019s assuming that countries like Australia and Saudi Arabia will get there by 2050, simply because they\u2019ve said they will,\u201d said Jennifer Morgan, executive director of Greenpeace International. \u201cWhen in reality they haven\u2019t put in place the funding or policies to make this happen.\u201d", "One issue being debated this week is whether countries should have to come back to the United Nations more frequently, perhaps annually, with stronger short-term pledges to cut emissions. At the moment, governments aren\u2019t expected to submit new plans until 2025.", "\u201cThat\u2019s a bit too late for many countries to strengthen their pledges for this decade, since they\u2019ll have built a lot of fossil-fuel infrastructure by then and will have locked in additional emissions,\u201d said Jennifer Tollmann, an analyst for E3G, a climate research group.", "Sabra Ibrahim Noordeen is the climate envoy for the Maldives, an archipelago of low-lying islands in the Indian Ocean that has been inhabited for thousands of years but could be inundated within three generations because of rising seas. She said countries like hers were depending on the summit to get it right.", "\u201cPlease get us to 1.5,\u201d she said.", "Even more contentious is the question of money, which has long been a big sticking point in global climate talks.", "A decade ago, the world\u2019s wealthiest nations pledged $100 billion per year by 2020 to help poorer countries transition to cleaner energy and protect themselves against the growing dangers from heat waves, floods, droughts and wildfires as the planet heats up.", "So far, those promises have not been met. By one estimate, wealthy countries are still falling short by tens of billions of dollars per year. And critics have said that even this money has been poorly targeted. A large fraction of aid to date has been handed out as loans, which developing countries often struggle to repay. And only a tiny sliver of financing has gone toward efforts to adapt to climate change.", "As the dangers from extreme weather rise, vulnerable countries say their financial needs are soaring.", "Sonam P. Wangdi, who leads a bloc of 47 nations known as the Least Developed Countries, pointed out that his home country of Bhutan bears little responsibility for global warming, since the nation currently absorbs more carbon dioxide from its vast forests than it emits from its cars and homes. Nonetheless, Bhutan faces severe risks from rising temperatures, with melting glaciers in the Himalayas already creating flash floods and mudslides that have devastated villages.", "\u201cWe have contributed the least to this problem yet we suffer disproportionately,\u201d Mr. Wangdi said. \u201cThere must be increasing support for adapting to impacts.\u201d", "At the same time, vulnerable countries are arguing for a separate funding mechanism to help compensate them for disasters that they can\u2019t adapt to, often referred to as \u201closs and damage.\u201d But that proposal faces opposition from wealthier countries, which fear it could open the door to future compensation claims.", "\u201cSo far the progress here is disappointing, and in a way frightening,\u201d Mr. Wangdi said. \u201cOur lives depend on decisions made here in Glasgow.\u201d", "Outside the conference center over the weekend, tens of thousands of protesters marched in lashing rains and bitter winds to urge countries to take more forceful measures to combat climate change.", "In an interview on the sidelines of the conference, former Vice President Al Gore said that he sympathized with protesters. \u201cGod bless them, it\u2019s a needed element for this whole process,\u201d Mr. Gore said. \u201cThat absolutely keeps the pressure on.\u201d", "But Mr. Gore added that the Glasgow summit was \u201calready a success,\u201d saying that \u201cthe direction of travel is toward net zero,\u201d and that was encouraging.", "Others argued that it was simplistic to expect a single conference to solve global warming. The Paris agreement was intended to add transparency to countries\u2019 climate plans and ratchet up pressure on world leaders to do more. But ultimately, the real test would be whether policymakers and businesses and activists make that vision a reality back home.", "\u201cThe day after Glasgow ends, there\u2019s still going to be a lot of work to do,\u201d said Kaveh Guilanpour, a vice president at the Center for Energy and Climate Solutions who has worked as a negotiator for various parties at past summits. \u201cA new agreement could set the foundations for what comes next, but it\u2019s up to all of us to maintain pressure after that. The problem is not going to be fixed in one go.\u201d", "\u201cWe may not really know how successful Glasgow was,\u201d he added, \u201cuntil a couple of years down the road.\u201d"]
